Context:
The text provides information about a nursing program offered by George Brown College focused on Operating Room Perioperative Nursing. The course is delivered through multimodal learning with both in-class and online components, including synchronous and asynchronous sessions, lab skills and simulations, and a clinical practical experience.

The first phase of the program, Nursing 4045, lasts for five weeks where students learn about ORNAC standards, surgical anatomy and instrumentation, surgical interventions and technologies, roles of scrub and circulating nurses, and lab skills. The second phase, Nursing 4046, is a clinical practicum lasting eight weeks (320 hours) where students consolidate their theory knowledge and develop the scrub and circulating nurse roles while gaining exposure to various surgical specialties. Students may participate in online discussions during their clinical placement through live video conferences and complete clinical assignments as per the course syllabus. Clinical experiences are coordinated by the program coordinator at hospitals within or outside the Greater Toronto Area (GTA), or at the hospital where the student is employed.

It's essential to note that students must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 to complete their clinical placements and meet course requirements. The text also mentions career and postgraduate study opportunities for those who complete this program, but no further details about these pathways are provided in the text.

Context:
Program: George Brown's Registered Nurse – Operating Room Perioperative Nursing graduate certificate program
Year(s) of completion for transfer credit application: The year the program was taken
Required Courses:
- NURS 4045: Operating Room Nursing – Theory and Labs
- NURS 4046: Operating Room Nursing – Practicum
Transfer credit application: Toronto Metropolitan University's Post-Diploma B.Sc.N. program
Learning Outcomes:
- Practice in a professional manner within legislated, ethical frameworks and exhibit cultural sensitivity
- Develop and sustain therapeutic relationships with surgical clients and their families
- Communicate effectively with surgical clients, healthcare team members, and others
- Participate effectively as a team member to support surgical clients' achievement of expected outcomes
- Integrate theory, principles, and concepts into competent surgical nursing practice
- Complete health assessments in a holistic, comprehensive, and analytical manner
- Prioritize and organize nursing healthcare
- Implement and evaluate nursing interventions competently
- Use technological tools to support surgical clients' achievement of expected health outcomes
- Apply principles of teaching-learning to promote surgical clients' health and wellness
- Practice according to the Standards of Practice of Operating Room Nurses Association of Canada, College of Nurses of Ontario, and Canadian Nurses' Association
- Emphasize sustainable practices minimizing environmental footprint
Costs:
- Domestic Tuition: $2,343.00 (estimated for one semester starting Fall 2023)
- Additional costs: Subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and later dates
Financial Assistance: RNs registered to practice in Ontario and employed in Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care (MOHLTC) priority areas may be eligible for a Nursing Education Initiative (NEI) grant.

Context:
* The Nursing Education Initiative (NEI) grant is available for individuals who are eligible and can be found at rnao.ca/education-funding/nei.
* This program is approved for OSAP funding, but applicants must meet OSAP eligibility criteria.
* Admission requirements for the RN program include: an RN, College of Nurses of Ontario without practice restrictions, BCLS certificate, current resume, interview by telephone, and recommended two years of surgical nursing experience in a hospital setting (no operating-room experience necessary).
* The program is open to both independent and sponsored student applicants.
* Independent students will complete an independent application, pay tuition fees, not be hired by a clinical agency, have a clinical placement arranged at an affiliate hospital by the program coordinator, and must complete pre-placement health form requirements and VSS upon program acceptance.
* Sponsored students are hired by the clinical agency prior to applying to the program, may or may not have their fees covered based on hiring contract details from the clinical agency, and complete their clinical placement at the hospital they are employed in.
* The program is open to domestic applicants only.
* Course exemptions may be granted for college or university credits. More information can be found in the Transfer Guide.
* Upon acceptance into the program, students must meet and complete all mandatory pre-placement requirements, including processing and providing proof of medical records (such as TDAP shot, COVID-19, MMR, Varicella, Hep B blood test reports/titres, and Two-Step TB Skin Test), a clear Vulnerable Sector Check renewed every year, a Basic Life Support certificate renewed every year, an annual flu shot, and a mask fit test renewed every two years.
* It will take up to 10 to 12 weeks to complete the pre-placement requirements.
* Students should verify George Brown College fee requirements.
* For more information about sponsorship to this program and how to meet admission requirements, contact nursing@georgebrown.ca.
* The text contains no information related to the specific program offered by the college.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Registered Nurse – Operating Room Perioperative Nursing Program (Postgraduate) S414 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
* The annual flu shot and mask fit test are required every two years and must be submitted to the ParaMed Placement Pass website by the program-specific deadline.
* COVID-19 vaccination is highly recommended for oral health care workers and required for placements in hospitals, long term care facilities, and some community agencies.
* The onsite WAVE dental clinic does not require vaccination but recommends it. Use of PPE will be required in all onsite clinics.
* Students who do not comply with the program's health policy and non-academic requirements or who do not submit all required documentation by deadlines may be excluded from clinical practicum, which could jeopardize academic standing and successful completion of the program.
* All costs associated with overall health requirements are the student's responsibility.
* The mandatory Pre-placement health form can be downloaded on the Clinical Pre-placement website.
* A Vulnerable Sector Check is required every year before entering into field or clinical placement, and it may take two to three months but could take up to eight months to complete.
* Students are responsible for ensuring that their Vulnerable Sector Check covers appropriateness for individuals working with vulnerable persons.
* Students must keep the original copy of their Vulnerable Sector Check and provide a clear check to start field or clinical placement; failure to do so will prevent them from completing the program.
